headline.print_headline: Charlie Rose, 73, Tobacco’s Friend in House
headline.seo: Rep. Charlie Rose, Ally of Tobacco Farmers, Dies at 73
headline.main: Representative Charlie Rose, Tobacco’s Friend in the House, Dies at 73

docs.abstract: Charlie Rose, a former United States representative from North Carolina who fought to protect the tobacco industry and its farmers when political pressure on the industry was on the rise, dies at age 73.
docs.lead_paragraph: As a Congressman in rural North Carolina, Mr. Rose worked to protect the tobacco industry and its farmers when political pressure on the industry was on the rise.
docs.snippet: As a Congressman in rural North Carolina, Mr. Rose worked to protect the tobacco industry and its farmers when political pressure on the industry was on the rise.

headline.main: Personal Health: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns that stroke poses a very real risk to some young people; notes that up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45, and that many of those cases go misdiagnosed, increasing the chance of lifelong impairment. Drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha's Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever. Today, with one arm useless and difficulty speaking, Mr. McGee, now 40, cannot work. He devotes most of his time to keeping as healthy as possible. Though he is able to drive and care for his daughter, now 7, everything takes longer, and he has trouble concentrating even on routine activities that others take in stride, like grocery shopping.
docs.snippet: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha's Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A  stroke  changed his life forever.   Today, with one arm...

headline.print_headline: Personal Health: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again
headline.main: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again

docs.abstract: Up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45 - and the sooner the correct diagnosis is made, the less likely the result will be lifelong impairment.
docs.snippet: Up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45 - and the sooner the correct diagnosis is made, the less likely the result will be lifelong impairment.
